infoSection.title: What is Joystream?
infoSection.text: Joystream is a decentralized video platform and blockchain. It's powered by the native $JOY token. We built an application called Atlas, which is similar to video platforms that you are already familiar with, but it uses the underlying Joystream blockchain to let you upload videos to your channel, build up your subscriber count, sell your videos as NFTs, and even create your own token for your channel so that people can invest in you. Those token holders can earn a share of the revenue you generate, get early access to your videos, and all sorts of cool things that you control.

language.question: What language is Joystream built on?
language.answer: Joystream is built using Substrate, in the Polkadot ecosystem. Joystream itself is its own blockchain, and the $JOY token is a native asset on our blockchain.

infoSection.title: Joystream as a DAO
infoSection.text:
DAO stands for Decentralized Autonomous Organization, and has been referred to as ‘An internet community with a shared bank account.
A DAO is the attempt to align the incentives of the consumers, or users of a product, with those running the organization. This is done by the use of tokens. By holding tokens, you become a partial owner of the organization, the same way that a stock gives you partial ownership of a company.
The difference is that you can use your ownership to influence the decisions of the organization. For example, you can apply to becoming a council member, or vote in the council member election. You can upload a proposal to suggest a new idea, and it will be voted on by the council. You can use your ownership to get your say in the direction of the organization, and not in a theoretical way, but in actual on-chain voting that cannot be defrauded. Also, everything is transparent, and out in the open for anyone to see, including budget & salaries.

infoSection2.title: Decentralized, and highly organized
infoSection2.text: One misconception about DAOs is that it's a free for all with no structure or leadership because there's no central owner. This is not the case. There is a system in place to organize all the people, much like in a traditional company.

pioneerInfo.text: Pioneer is our state of the art application that we use for all governance related things. This is where you keep track of everything. Discuss proposals, vote on elections & proposals, ee the finances in the treasury, and so on. Everything governance related is found in Pioneer.

infoSection.title: What is the Founding Members program?
infoSection.text:
The Founding Members program is like an ambassador program where at least 15% of the genesis supply of JOY tokens will be allocated to people who contribute to the organization in a meaningful way.
Joystream, which you know by now, is a decentralized organization. This means we need people in place to run and operate the whole platform, and so we thought the best way to attract those people.. people like you.. would be to bribe you.
15% of JOY tokens will be split between the Founding Members, and anyone, yourself included, can become a Founding Member simply by contributing meaningful work to the platform.

infoSection2.title: Get rewarded for referring people
infoSection2.text: The referral program gives you an incentive to tell people that you think would make a good fit for the Founding Members program about it. If they become a founding member, and put you down as the person who referred them, you will get a nice reward for doing so.

tasksInfo.title: 4 things you can do to become a FM

task1.title: Join the Council
task1.text: Join the Council and vote on proposals, collaborate with Working Groups, and so on

task2.title: Join a Working Group
task2.text: Join one of the working groups and do the work to meet their objectives

task3.title: Work on pre defined Bounties
task3.text: Pre defined Bounties are one-off tasks that move the project forward

task4.title: Make your own Bounty
task4.text: If you see something to fix, or an opportunity to improve something, you can make your own bounty

step1.title: Get clear on what you can offer
step1.text: Are you a great communicator? graphic designer? video editor? do you like chatting to people in discord and helping them learn more about the project? are you a developer? and so on. Get clear on what you can offer.

step2.title: Figure out some way to contribute (we can help)
step2.text: Find some problem to fix, or opportunity to improve. We have "Integrators" in discord whose job it is to help people like you get involved in the project, they can help you get clarity on this. All you have to do is join discord and get in touch with an integrator.

step3.title: Get started!
step3.text: Once you have identified something you can work on, it's time to do that job. I'd recommend starting small, to just get the ball rolling. You can worry about picking the perfect task later on, for now, just get going, get integrated.

section1.title: Swasilenko
section1.text: “Don't be scared and don't give up! Everything is real. Dive deep in the project. Try to see problems from the inside and propose their solutions. Do things which other didn't do.”

section2.title: l1dev
section2.text: “Joining a DAO is like arriving at a construction site. if you are lucky someone placed integrators at the fence to hand you a guide. if not you got to start bugging workers carrying stuff or just grab your tools and start building a wall.”

section3.title: Isonar
section3.text: “In DAOs, there usually isn't a single communication point or a "call tree". That means that you have to be prepared to get the information you need yourself, which can be hard sometimes. Second advice: look for a good first task for yourself. There are no shortage of things you can do, but strive to get a task that will make your skills really stand out. You may be a very highly professional videomaker, or coder, or writer, but you can't just send your portfolio and hope DAO will appreciate your skills and experience. Skills have to be proven here almost "from scratch". Show your professionalism, and make yourself visible to the community.

section4.title: 0x2bc
section4.text: “My two cents. First - allocate some time forJoystream activities, it may be even 20-30 minutes, but you should work consistently, day by day. Second - don't hesitate to ask questions. Third - Don't give up even if you are puzzled by work. Just split the task into pieces, do them step by step”

section5.title: Chiffah
section5.text: “Be brave, curious, don't be afraid to ask questions and speak your mind. It is your opinion, and not what seems right/appropriate/convenient to the community. The main thing is not to be hypocritical. And you will be surprised how many interesting people will want to help you and what opportunities will open up!”

question1.question: Who is the Founding Member’s program for?
question1.answer: Founding Members can be developers, video content creators, video editors, writers, storage and bandwidth providers, among many other things. If you think you can help the project, you can become FM.

question2.question: How long does it take to become a FM?
question2.answer: There is no set time frame, as your ability to become a Founding Member is based on valuable contributions. We have seen people become Founding Members in as little as 1 month.

question3.question: What do I need to do to become a FM?
question3.answer: In short, contribute to the project in a meaningful way. Council work, Working groups, or bounties is how to earn your stripes.

page4.title: What is the Council?
page4.subtitle: Everything you need to know about the group of people who lead the governance side of Joystream, including how you can become one

infoSection.title: What is the Council?
infoSection.text: The Joystream council is a group of individuals that have been elected by token holders to improve the platform. They're sort of the leaders of the platform, who strategically vote on proposals, hire and fire Working Group leads, give assignments, and so on. They're sort of a mix of a board member and a chief executive, if we think of traditional company structure.

infoSection2.title: What makes a good Council Member?
infoSection2.text:
Apart from voting on proposals and administrative tasks, council members are there to improve the platform.
Maybe someone submitted a proposal that has a good core idea, but the proposal wasn't very good. It'll be in the best interest of the council member to help the person out, perhaps getting on a call with them, and helping them making the argument more compelling.
Or they might help a WG lead figure out what new role they need to hire to reach the WG objectives. They're fundamentally there to help, and serve. What other characteristics do Council members people have?

task1.title: Knowledge
task1.text: Council members typically have a good knowledge of Joystream, or at least are very quick learners.

task2.title: Diplomacy
task2.text: Council members can hash out disagreements with civil debate, and maintain a high level of professionalism

task3.title: Activity and commitment
task3.text: The blockchain industry moves very fast and people need to stay engaged in the community to know what's happening.

task4.title: Long term perspective
task4.text: Council members want to see Joystream succeed for a very long time, and short term gratification is not their objective.

question1.question: What do council members do?
question1.answer: They're sort of the leaders of the platform, who strategically vote on proposals, hire and fire Working Group leads, give assignments, and so on. So in essence the council is there to ensure that the platform improves, primarily by voting on proposals that have been submitted, and also administrative things like budgets and paying workers.

question2.question: How do I become a council member?
question2.answer: The process of becoming a council member consists of running for a council seat on chain, and getting people to stake tJOY by voting for you.

question3.question: How does voting of council members work?
question3.answer: Voters stake tJOY as a way to cast their vote.

page5.title: What are Working Groups?
page5.subtitle: Working groups are like company departments collectively working towards some specific objective

infoSection.title: What are Working Groups?
infoSection.text: Think of working groups like company departments, like a Marketing Department for example. The Marketing department would have a head of that department, and in Joystream we have Working Group Leads. The WG lead is responsible for reaching the objectives of the WG, and those are agreed upon with the council, who holds the WG lead accountable. The same goes for a Curation working group, or Storage working group, and so on.

storageProviders.title: Storage Providers
storageProviders.text: Storage Providers are responsible for storing and providing platform content

operationsGroup.title: Operations Group
operationsGroup.text: Operations Working Group encompases all the activites that don't require privileges on chain like: Development, Management, Marketing.

curators.title: Curators
curators.text: Content Curators are responsible for ensuring that all content is uploaded correctly and in line with the terms of service.

distributors.title: Distributors
distributors.text: Distribution Working Group is responsible for running and maintaining distributor nodes that deliver large volumes of upstream data to a large number of simultaneous end users.

question1.question: What do workers do?
question1.answer: This of course depends on which Working Group they’re part of, but they do all types of tasks to help achieve the WG objectives, the same way an employee of a traditional company works to achieve the objectives of their department.

page6.title: What are bounties?
page6.subtitle: Everything you need to understand about how to make a living by working on bounties, and even creating your own bounty

infoSection.title: What are bounties?
infoSection.text: A Bounty is a one-off task that needs to get done, but doesn't warrant a full-time position like a working group. Think of it like a gig. These types of one-off gigs are plentiful, and new ones are always popping up. Anyone can suggest a Bounty that doesn't already exist to also be added, and of course, whoever successfully completes a Bounty is rewarded by the council.

bounties.title: Bounties
bounties.text: Bounties are tasks which anyone can attempt to tackle in a exchange for some reward. To contribute in earning via Bounties you need to contact one of our Integrators on Discord.

page7.title: How to make a living as a video creator
page7.subtitle: Learn how to create and monetize on Joystream using video NFTs, social tokens, and even getting paid by Joystream itself

infoSection.title: How to make a living as a video creator
infoSection.text:
Atlas is in many ways similar to video applications you are already familiar with, but it's on the blockchain, and decentralized, and it has some really amazing features like the ability to sell your videos as NFTs, and create a token for your own channel where subscribers, or any consumer of your content, can invest in you as a creator.
It's a new way for content creators to make a living, without being at the mercy of the platform they publish on.

atlasInfo1.title: YouTube sync program
atlasInfo1.text: YouTube sync is a way to back up your content automatically on Atlas, and of course being able to then sell the video as an NFT, and it’s a seamless automated experience.

atlasInfo2.title: Social Tokens
atlasInfo2.text: With social tokens creators can even let token holders earn a share of the revenue they generate, give early access to content, and all sorts of cool things. Creators are loving this new way of making a living, where they are less reliant on having to agree on things like the politics of the platform they use, or having to pander to advertisers. Now creators can focus on making the content they want, and monetize that.

atlasInfo3.title: NFT’s
atlasInfo3.text: With the ability to sell your content as NFTs, or have people invest in you as a creator by purchasing your token it gives creators new ways to monetize their content.

atlasInfo4.title: Atlas
atlasInfo4.text: Atlas is the flagship content consumer and publishing app for Joystream. Watch videos, follow creators and discover new featured content, or create a channel and build your audience.

question1.question: How do NFTs work?
question1.answer: Video NFTs work in many ways similarly to what you may already be used to on other platforms. Once you upload a video you can decide to issue it as an NFT, and you can sell it via auction, fixed price, among other options.

question2.question: What are Social Tokens?
question2.answer: You can turn your channel on Atlas into its own token. This allows investors to support and speculate on you as a creator, and they can get benefits  such as revenue share, early content access, among other things.
